description.summary: An enormous moose-like creature with stiff, jointless legs that cannot bend, forcing it to sleep leaning against trees; can be killed by sawing through the supporting tree.
description.full: The Hugag is a fearsome critter resembling an enormous moose but with one critical flaw: its legs are completely stiff and jointless, unable to bend at all. Because it cannot lie down, the Hugag must sleep standing upright, leaning against a tree for support. This vulnerability makes the creature easy prey for clever lumberjacks, who simply saw through the supporting tree. When the tree falls, the Hugag topples over and cannot get back up. According to the tall tales, this is how lumberjacks deal with the otherwise formidable creature. The Hugag represents the fearsome critter tradition's love of absurd biological flaws that create equally absurd hunting methods.

etymology.meaning: Unknown; typical nonsense naming of fearsome critters

features.description: Legs completely rigid without joints, cannot bend
Extremely long upper lip in some accounts

physical.morphology: Moose-like but enormous and with impossibly stiff, jointless legs

abilities.description: Can remain standing indefinitely due to rigid legs

patterns: Cannot lie down due to stiff legs
Cannot get up if knocked over

range.description: Northern forests with large trees suitable for leaning

origins.cultural_roots: American occupational folklore from lumber camps
origins.folklore_connections: Represents absurd biological flaw exploited through lumberjack expertise

folklore.beliefs: Killed by sawing support tree; represents how lumberjack skills defeat creatures

literature: Fearsome Creatures of the Lumberwoods by William T. Cox (1910)
